availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

body.p: A Kentucky attorney, judge, and politician. Received a common education. Studied law and admitted to the bar. Practiced law in Mount Sterling, Kentucky. Married to Mary V. F. Moore. Father of Helen/an Moore. Member of the Whig Party and Democratic Party. Served as Circuit Court judge of the 10th Kentucky Judicial District from 1851 to 1859. Served as a member of the Council of Ten in the Provisional Government of Kentucky. Served the Tenth Congressional District as a member of the First and Second Confederate Congress in the House of Representatives from 1862 to 1865.

bibl.p: Ezra J. Warner and W. Buck Yearns, Biographical Register of the Confederate Congress (Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1975), 179; Lewis Collins and Richard Collins, History of Kentucky, vol. 1 (Collins & Company, 1882), 353; LeRoy P. Graf, et al., eds., The Papers of Andrew Johnson: September 1865,--January 1866, vol. 9 (Knoxville: University of Tennessee Press, 1967), 185; “James William Moore,” (http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=6868706) (accessed January 19, 2017); “Death of Judge James W. Moore,” Courier-Journal (Louisville, Ky.), September 20, 1877; Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Montgomery County, District No 1.
